entry.title: The description and encoding of structure
entry.summary: Much metadata is fairly stright forward. A book does have a title and an author. That's usually no big deal. We've been able to handle that for centuries. A digital book has chapters, and everything you might want to know may be in chapter two on page seventyfive. Or someone may tell you the solution to your problems after a quarter of an hour in some video on YouTube. Now, how do we cope with this?

div.p: Many things in life can best be represented as trees. Indeed, life itself is a tree of various life forms. We have the animal and plant kingdoms, and these main categories are further sub-divided into phylae, classes, genera. The animal kingdom is divided into invertebrates and vertebrates. The latter include amphibians, reptiles, birds and mammals. Human knowledge is also represented as a tree.

A lot of other things are trees. Hence, philosophers, mathematicins and computer scientists have spent efforts on how to understand how to model stuff as trees. Within library & information science we have used the term classification systems for centuries, I suppose, and more recently we have started to talk about ontologies and knowledge organization. There are a lot of theory and a lot of standards in this area. Systems like topic maps (see also topicmaps.org) and more recently Simple Knowledge Organization System SKOS) are available for those who need a standard for knowledge organization.

On a very down to earth level, I tend to think of controlled vocabularies as filters and navigators. The latter are trees and may contain many terms arranged into a tree of arbitrary depth. The filters are more like traditional facets. Think of Yahoo in the nineties. You could browse into Tuscany and get a very long list of resources. Then there was a bar at the top where you could choose between "Shopping", "Eating out", "Accomodation", "Travel" and so forth. These are broader categorizations that apply to Firenze as well as Siena or any place you may want to visit. We in the Web business call them filters or facets.

From a user perspective, you have to take into account that there are two cognitive processes involved when using services that employ filters and navigators. The first one is much more fundamental, and is by nurture and possibly nature a part of the human mind: This is to say: Ah Tuscany, that is a part of Italy, isn't it. It's like distinguishing between a wasp and a bumble bee. On an evolutionary time-scale we've benefitted from being able to say, this is edible this is not, or this one has a sting and is likely to use it. This is to recognize something when you see it. The opposite is a much more difficult cognitive process: I want to know something about Tuscany: Ok, I then start clicking on Italy. You have to recollect, not only recognize, more to begin with. Remembering might not be trivial. To know in advance things like that frogs are amphibians and that diabetes is an endocrinological disorder. On the other hand, it helps to know such things when doing successfully searching in Google as well.

There are structures that are inside a resource, and that require navigation as well. As a first approximation we can assume that any digital resource, such as digital resource such as an electronic book is an ordered hierarchy of content objects. That view has been questioned, and it is for instance claimed that just an ordinary text consists of many, overlapping hierarchies.
